coredata.dc:description: The molecular oxygen activation (MOA) process tends to be the rate-limiting step for photocatalytic selective organic transformation such as aromatic alcohol oxidation. Herein, using the plasmonic 0D/2D W18O49/ZnIn2S4 (WOZ) heterojunctions as a model system, we firstly shed light on the ultra-efficient MOA origin of the synergism of photothermal effect and continuous hot electrons injection through both experimental and DFT calculations. This synergistic action not only enhances the generation rate of •O2 ¯ and reduces the activation energy barrier, but also significantly increases the adsorption of the O2 and activates it more easily, thus achieving efficient photocatalytic selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde. Meanwhile, the charge separation and transfer processes involved in O2 activation can be further optimized with the Z-scheme transfer route. This work would provide an exciting opportunity to construct more active photothermal catalysts with ultra-high efficiency of MOA for a wide variety of organic transformations with solar energy.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The molecular oxygen activation (MOA) process tends to be the rate-limiting step for photocatalytic selective organic transformation such as aromatic alcohol oxidation. Herein, using the plasmonic 0D/2D W18O49/ZnIn2S4 (WOZ) heterojunctions as a model system, we firstly shed light on the ultra-efficient MOA origin of the synergism of photothermal effect and continuous hot electrons injection through both experimental and DFT calculations. This synergistic action not only enhances the generation rate of •O2 ¯ and reduces the activation energy barrier, but also significantly increases the adsorption of the O2 and activates it more easily, thus achieving efficient photocatalytic selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde. Meanwhile, the charge separation and transfer processes involved in O2 activation can be further optimized with the Z-scheme transfer route. This work would provide an exciting opportunity to construct more active photothermal catalysts with ultra-high efficiency of MOA for a wide variety of organic transformations with solar energy.

ce:section.ce:para: Selective oxidation of aromatic alcohols, as a kind of fundamental organic transformation, is of great significance for the basic research and practical production process [1,2]. Because their corresponding aldehydes are essential for the synthesis of fine chemicals and chemical intermediates. However, the traditional approaches of selective oxidation suffer from many shortcomings such as low controllability, harsh reaction conditions and the use of environmentally harmful as well as toxic oxidants, which inevitably lead to tremendous energy waste and serious environmental pollution [3]. In recent years, due to the merits of mild reaction conditions and no need for hazardous oxidants, photocatalytic technology has been demonstrated as a convenient, environmentally friendly, and cost-saving method for selective oxidation of aromatic alcohols [4–6]. The molecular oxygen activation (MOA) process tends to be the rate-limiting step for selective organic transformation such as aromatic alcohol oxidation [7,8]. As is well known, the efficient MOA can produce various reactive oxygen species such as superoxide (•O2 ¯) and singlet oxygen (1O2), which have proven to be vital active sources of photocatalytic selective oxidation of aromatic alcohols [9–11]. Therefore, more and more attention has been attached to the construction of novel wide spectrum responsive photocatalysts with high efficiency of MOA for selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol (BA) to benzaldehyde (BAD) [12,13], and much effort has been devoted to this research in the past few years.

As a typical n-type semiconductor, the ternary sulfide photocatalyst of ZnIn2S4 (ZIS) possesses a suitable bandgap (~2.5 eV), unique two-dimension (2D) structure, and massive surface areas, which make it widely investigated for the application of photocatalytic selective oxidation of BA [14–17]. However, due to the restrictions of poor molecular oxygen activation efficiency, insufficient absorption of visible light and rapid recombination of charge carriers [18,19], the photocatalytic activity of pure ZIS is still undesirable. There is a certain distance away from its practical application. Notably, researchers mainly concentrate the modification methods of pure ZIS on improving separation efficiency of the photogenerated carriers or expanding the light response range [20–23], while less on enhancing the activation of the molecular oxygen in the field of photocatalytic organic synthesis.

Recently, many studies have manifested that the introduction of the photothermal effect is a highly effective strategy to improve photocatalytic activity, and photocatalytic organic conversion is no exception [24–27]. When a photothermal effect is integrated into the photocatalyst, the following advantages can be gained. Firstly, the solar energy can be efficiently converted to heat by the photothermal materials and the local ambient temperature will be raised, which results in a faster collision rate and more efficient collisions of molecules [28]. Secondly, the high surface temperature of photocatalyst promotes the dissociative adsorption of reactant molecules [29]. Thirdly, the electrons at electron traps can be re-emitted and rapidly transfer to the surface of the photocatalyst through the photothermal effect, thus enhancing the efficiency of electron utilization [30]. Loading of plasmonic metal (e.g., Pt, Au, Ag,) to realize a localized surface plasmon resonances (LSPR) effect is regarded as an effective approach to realize the photothermal effect [31,32]. Nevertheless, such noble metals are often highly rare and expensive, which extremely restricted their large-scale application.

Recently, several low cost and noble-metal-free plasmonic semiconductor materials such as WO3−x [33,34], Cu2−xS [35,36], and MoO3−x [37,38] have drawn extensive attention among researchers. Due to the presence of element vacancies, an LSPRs effect can be achieved on these semiconductor surfaces, thus leading to the photothermal effect [39]. In particular, the n-type semiconductor W18O49 with a wide and intense LSPR absorption centered at 700 nm has become a promising and attractive photosensitive material for solar energy conversion and water purification in the full spectrum (UV–vis NIR) region [40]. In addition, the oxygen vacancies of W18O49 can also increase the reactive sites to improve the photocatalytic property [41]. Besides achieving a photothermal effect, the LSPRs effect can simultaneously extend the light response range and accelerate charge carriers transfer of photocatalysts [42]. More importantly, nonmetallic plasmonic W18049 can generate hot electrons continuously induced by LSPR [43,44]. These hot electrons with higher energy can activate reactants and reduce the activation barrier of MOA, which is conducive to photocatalytic organic transformations [45]. It is envisaged that a combination of photothermal effect and continuous hot electrons generation might greatly enhance the molecular oxygen activation, although this remains unexplored thus far.

On the basis of the aforementioned considerations, we explore the synergism of photothermal effect and continuous hot electrons injection induced efficient MOA using a photothermal catalysis platform for the first time. The plasmonic 0D/2D W18O49/ZIS heterojunctions with photothermal effect were successfully fabricated through a facile water-bath heating method. The optimized W18O49/ZIS heterojunctions exhibit excellent catalytic activity (68.6%) and selectivity (>99.0%) in the oxidation of BA to BAD, superior to those of pure W18O49 and ZIS. The W18O49/ZIS heterojunctions show greater light absorption capacity and faster charge separation and transfer. More importantly, the efficiency of MOA over W18O49/ZIS heterojunctions was significantly improved through the synergistic action of photothermal effect and continuous hot electrons generation, thus achieving high photocatalytic activity. We propose and discuss the mechanistic insights into the synergistic action induced the high selectivity and activity in photocatalytic oxidation of BA through both experimental and theoretical calculation. This work can provide new insight into the construction of more active photothermal catalysts for a wide variety of organic transformations with solar energy.

Indium chloride tetrahydrate (InCl3.4H2O), thioacetamide (TAA), Zinc chloride (ZnCl2), Tungsten hexachloride (WCl6), Polyacrylic acid (PAA, M.w = 2000), diethylene glycol (DEG), benzyl alcohol (BA) and trifluoro toluene (BTF) was offered by Aladdin Industrial Corporation. All reagents above were used as received without further purification.

Typically, 0.4 mmol Zn(CH3COO)2.2H2O, 0.8 mmol InCl3.4 H2O and 1.6 mmol TAA were dissolved in a mixture of 15 mL deionized water and 15 mL absolute ethanol under constant magnetic stirring 30 min to form a transparent and homogeneous solution. Next, the precursor solution was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and maintained at 180 °C for 24 h. After the autoclave was cooled down to ambient temperature, the resulted precipitation was sonicated continuously for some time and then washed with deionized water and absolute ethanol. Finally, the pure ZnIn2S4 nanosheets, denoted as ZIS, were obtained by vacuum freeze-drying.

W18O49/ZnIn2S4 heterojunctions were prepared using a facile water-bath heating method with a slight modification [46,47]. Briefly, 50 mg WCl6 and 20 mg PAA were added into a 50 mL three-necked flask with 20 mL DEG. Subsequently, a certain amount of ZIS nanosheets (20, 40, 60, or 80 mg) was dispersed into the above-mixed solution. Under the protection of N2, the flask was treated at 60 °C with continual stir for 30 min. Subsequently, the mixed solution was heated to 180 °C for 1 h. After the product cooling down, W18O49/ZIS heterojunctions were obtained by centrifugation and washed with deionized water, and finally dried in the vacuum freeze-drying. The obtained W18O49/ZnIn2S4 samples were marked as WOZ-x (x = 20, 40, 60, and 80, respectively), where x was the amount of added ZIS. The synthesis route of W18O49/ZnIn2S4 heterojunctions is shown in Fig. 1. In order to contrast, the pure W18O49 nanodots were synthesized under the same reaction conditions without the addition of ZIS.

The crystalline structures of the synthesized photocatalysts were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku Smartlab SE, Japan). The surface Morphologies and detailed microstructures were analyzed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Titan G2 60–300, FEI, USA). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer equipped with Al Kα excitation. All the binding energy values were calibrated with respect to C 1s peak at 284.8 eV. Diffuse Reflectance Spectra (DRS) were collected using a Shimadzu UV-3600 UV-Vis-NIR spectrometer and BaSO4 was used as the reflectance standard sample. Photoluminescence (PL) spectra and the time-resolved transient photoluminescence (TRPL) spectra were obtained from an Edinburgh instrument FLS1000 fluorescence spectrometer. The electrochemical measurements, including photocurrent, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and Mott-Schottky analysis, were performed on a CHI 660 C electrochemical workstation (CHI Inc., USA). The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) data were recorded using a Bruker Elexsys E540 spectrometer.

The specific details of photocatalytic selective oxidation of BA to BAD are as follows: 40 mg photocatalyst, 0.2 mmol BA and 10 mL BTF were added into a 25 mL three-neck flask. After bubbled with O2 for 30 min to reach adsorption-desorption equilibrium, the suspension was irradiated under a 300 W Xe lamp with a 400 nm cut-off filter via constant magnetic stirring. The reaction was conducted in 1 bar O2 reaction atmosphere. The organic product was analyzed by gas chromatography-mass spectrum (GC–MS, Shimadzu QP2010 Ultra, Japan) with an HP-5 capillary column.

The simulation calculation of the work function, the O2 adsorption energy and the charge density difference is carried out by using PAW method of VASP code. The PBE functional within the GGA was chosen as the exchange-correlation functional using a cutoff energy of 400 eV. Vanderbilt ultrasoft pseudopotentials were also adopted throughout the analysis to change the charges of catalysts’ surface. The convergence tolerance for the energy was set to 1.0 × 10−5 eV, as well as the convergence force threshold of 0.01 eV Å-1. In addition, the k-point grids were set to 2 × 2 × 2 for ZIS, 2 × 1 × 1 for W18O49 and 2 × 2 × 1 for WOZ, respectively, based on Monkhorst–Pack scheme. The adsorption energy (Eads) of the O2 was determined according to Eads = Etotal – Esurface - Eoxygen, where Etotal is the total energy of the adsorbed O2 with catalyst surface, Esurface is the energy of the empty surface, and Eoxygen represents the energy of the O2.
The detailed description of the photothermal test and the degradation experiment of NBT are shown in Text S1 and Text S2 of Supporting information, respectively.

The XRD patterns of ZIS, W18O49 and WOZ heterojunctions are displayed in Fig. 2(a). For pure ZIS, five distinct diffraction peaks can be observed at 2θ= 21.78, 27.81, 30.1, 47.59 and 52.1°, which are in good consistent with the (0 0 6), (1 0 2), (1 0 4), (1 1 0) and (1 0 1 2) crystal planes of hexagonal phase ZnIn2S4 (JCPDS No.652023) [15,16]. And all the diffraction peaks of as-prepared W18O49 match well with monoclinic phase W18O49 (JCPDS No. 712450) [46,47]. For WOZ heterojunctions, besides the diffraction peaks of ZIS, it can be found that there is a characteristic peak at 23.47° belonging to (0 1 0) crystal facets of W18O49. With the increasing ratio of ZIS in WOZ heterojunctions, the peak intensities of the (0 0 6) and (1 1 0) crystal facets of ZIS gradually strengthen, while the peak intensity of the (0 1 0) crystal facet of W18O49 decreases gradually. In addition, no change can be found in the crystallographic structure of ZnIn2S4 in composites after coupling with W18O49. The XRD results confirm the successful construction of WOZ heterojunctions.

To understand the surface elemental composition and the valence state of the obtained photocatalysts, XPS characterization of ZIS, W18O49 and WOZ-60 composites were conducted. The survey XPS spectra (Fig. S1) demonstrate the existence of W, O, Zn, In, and S elements in the WOZ-60 heterojunctions. As displayed in Fig. 2(b), the W 4f spectra of W18O49 nanodots are fitted into two categories of peaks: one is marked as 4f5/2 (37.4 eV) and 4f7/2 (35.4 eV) of W6+ state; the other is attributed to 4f5/2 (36.5 eV) and 4f7/2 (34.8 eV) of W5+ state. The presence of low-valence W species (W5+) demonstrates the plenty of oxygen vacancies and localized electrons in W18O49 nanodots, which lead to an LSPRs effect. As shown in Fig. 2c, two main peaks are observed at 530.7 and 529.5 eV in the O 1s spectrum of W18O49, which originated from the oxygen species adsorbed at oxygen vacancies and the lattice oxygen in W18O49, respectively. For pure ZIS, two characteristic peaks can be both observed in the Zn 2p and In 3d spectra, one at 1044.1 and 1021.0 eV (Fig. 2d) and the other at 452.1 and 444.3 eV (Fig. 2e). The former is ascribed to the Zn 2p3/2 and Zn 2p1/2 of Zn2+ state, while the latter corresponds to the In 3d5/2 and In 3d3/2 of In3+ state. Fig. 2(f) shows that the S 2p spectra of ZIS nanosheets are fitted into two peaks at 162.2 and 161.0 eV, which are assigned to the S 2p1/2 and S 2p3/2 of S2- state. It is noted from the comparison between WOZ-60 composites and pure ZIS or W18O49 that the binding energies of Zn 2p, In 3d and S 2p peaks display positive shifts and the binding energies of O 1 show negative shifts. The XPS results indicate the formation of an internal electric field and intimate contact at the interface between ZIS and W18O49, which can promote the charge separation and transfer and enhance the photocatalytic activity [15].

The morphologies of ZIS, W18O49 and WOZ heterojunctions are characterized by TEM and HRTEM. As shown in Fig. 3(a), the as-prepared W18O49 samples display a homogeneously dispersed spherical morphology with particles size in a range from 10 to 20 nm. From the TEM image of ZIS (Fig. 3b), it can be seen that the pristine ZIS shows the ultrathin nanosheets morphology and is almost transparent. Generally, the ultrathin nanosheets morphology makes ZIS a higher specific surface area, which can offer more active sites and is conducive to load nanodots [48]. Fig. 3(c) shows the morphology of WOZ-60 heterojunctions. Obviously, W18O49 nanodots are uniformly and tightly anchored on the surface of ZIS nanosheets. To further prove the existence of the W18O49/ZIS heterojunctions, the nanoscale structure of WOZ composites is investigated by the HRTEM. As illustrated in Fig. 3(d) and (e), the co-existence of W18O49 and ZIS can be clearly observed. The calculated lattice spacing of 0.38 nm and 0.32 nm is ascribed to the (0 1 0) crystal facets of W18O49 and (1 0 2) crystal facets of ZIS, respectively. Moreover, the EDS elemental mapping images of WOZ-60 (Fig. 3f–g) substantiate the presence of W, O, Zn, In, and S elements in the WOZ-60 heterojunctions, which is in line with the preceding XPS results. To a great extent, these results indicate the formation of heterojunction between W18O49 and ZIS, and their tight interface contact is beneficial to accelerate the transfer of charge carriers and enhance photocatalytic performance [17].

The N2 adsorption-desorption measurement was applied to determine the BET surface area and pore structure of ZIS and WOZ composites. The corresponding results are displayed in Fig. S2 and Table S1. Plainly, the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of all the samples possess a typical type-IV isotherm with an H3 adsorption hysteresis loops, implying that as-prepared photocatalysts have the mesopores structure. Moreover, the pore diameters of ZIS, WOZ-80, WOZ-60, WOZ-40 and WOZ-20 are 2.07, 2.67, 2.78, 3.02,and 3.08 nm, further demonstrating their mesopores structure. And their corresponding BET specific surface area is 48.61, 53.87, 63.07, 72.58, and 79.09 m2/g, respectively. It is noticeable that all the surface areas of WOZ composites are larger than that of pure ZIS. Generally, the higher surface area of WOZ heterojunctions can enhance the absorption ability to reactants, and expose more activity sites, thus achieving high-efficiency photocatalytic performance.

The UV–vis–NIR absorption spectra were measured to obtain the optical properties of as-prepared photocatalysts. As shown in Fig. 4(a), the light absorption edges of pure ZIS and W18O49 are located at 470 nm and 540 nm, respectively. Moreover, the pure W18O49 exhibits a broad visible/NIR absorption, which is ascribed to the LSPRs effect caused by the O vacancies. After coupling ZIS nanosheets with W18O49 nanodots, the light absorption edge of WOZ composites has a clear red shift compared with pure ZIS. Also, the WOZ composites show a strong absorption ability in the range of visible light and NIR light. In order to determine the band structure of pure ZIS and W18O49, the Tauc plot was acquired based on the Kubelka–Munk formula αhѵ1/n = A(hѵ-Eg) [16,39]. As can be seen from Fig. 4(b), the bandgap energy (Eg) values of ZIS and W18O49 are 2.58 and 2.94 eV, respectively.

In addition, the Mott-Schottky plots of ZIS and W18O49 were measured to acquire the flat-band potential and the corresponding results are displayed in Fig. 4(c) and (d). The flat-band potentials (Efb) of ZIS and W18O49 are located at −0.57 V vs. Ag/AgCl and 0.41 V vs. Ag/AgCl. What’s more, both ZIS and W18O49 belong to n-type semiconductors due to the positive slopes over the Mott-Schottky curve of ZIS and W18O49. As known, the value of Efb is generally 0.2 V positive than that of the conduction band potentials (ECB) of n-type semiconductors [49,50]. Therefore, the ECB are located at −0.77 V vs. Ag/AgCl for ZIS and 0.21 V vs. Ag/AgCl for W18O49, which match with −0.53 V vs. NHE and 0.45 V vs. NHE (ENHE = EAg/AgCl + 0.24 V). And the position of the valance band potentials (EVB) is situated at 2.05 V vs. NHE for ZIS and 2.49 V vs. NHE for W18O49 according to the formula EVB = ECB + Eg.

The presence of photothermal effect over WOZ composites was proved under the 300 W Xe light irradiation. As illustrated in Fig. 5(a), after 240 s of simulated solar light irradiation, a little increase of the surface temperature appeared over pure ZIS, while a quick surface temperature increase can be observed over WOZ composites, indicating the existence of the photothermal effect over WOZ composites. Moreover, the in-situ temperature of different photocatalytic systems was recorded under irradiation. As displayed in Fig. 5(b), compared with the blank group, the temperature of the ZIS suspension shows a negligible change, while the temperature of the WOZ-60 suspension increases greatly and it can reach 54.6 °C, which further confirm that WOZ heterojunctions have a photothermal effect. The photothermal effect of WOZ heterojunctions is attributed to the LSPRs effect on the W18O49 nanodots surfaces. Generally, the photothermal effect not only can accelerate the mobility of photogenerated carriers, but also enhance the photoexcitation efficiency, which is conducive to photocatalytic activity [28–30].

The photocatalytic activity was probed for selective oxidation of BA to BAD under the 300 W Xe light irradiation. As illustrated in Fig. 5(c), all the photocatalysts display high selectivity for oxidation of BA to BAD (>99%). However, the photocatalytic performance of both pure ZIS and W18O49 is low and the conversion of BA over them is 22.4% and 3.7%, respectively. After W18O49 nanodots are deposited on the surface of ZIS nanosheets, the conversion of BA is greatly improved. The conversion of BA over WOZ-20, WOZ-40, WOZ-60 and WOZ-80 is 57.3%, 64.7%, 68.6% and 61.4%, respectively. Obviously, the WOZ-60 sample exhibits the highest photocatalytic activity of selective oxidation BA, and its conversion of BA is 3.1 and 18.6 times of pure ZIS and W18O49, respectively. The generated amounts of BAD with the change of time over different photocatalysts are shown in Fig. 5(d). And using the generated millimoles of BAD per hour per gram of the photocatalyst as the evaluation index, the corresponding BDA generation rates of as-prepared photocatalysts are displayed in Fig. S3a. It is clear that the WOZ-60 photocatalysts show the maximum BDA generation rate, which can reach 1.143 mmol g−1 h−1. Moreover, as illustrated in Table S2, the BDA generation rate of WOZ-60 is higher than most of the other zinc–indium-sulfide-based and tungsten-oxide-based photocatalysts, indicating the WOZ-60 possess extremely attractive advantages for aerobic selective alcohol oxidation. As can be seen from Fig. S3b, photocatalyst, O2 and light are the necessary conditions for oxidation of BA to BAD.

To further explore the relationships between the thermal effect and the photocatalytic activity, the reaction temperature was kept constant to eliminate the effect of photoinduced heat. As can be seen from Fig. 5e, when the reaction temperature is fixed at 10 °C, 25 °C, 40 °C and 55 °C, the conversion of BA over WOZ-60 is 46.4%, 56.3%, 64.2% and 71.5%, respectively. The reaction rate of BA selective oxidation accelerates as temperature increased. And the conversion of BA at 55 °C is the highest, which is similar to the condition without control temperature. Fig. 5(f) shows the conversion of BA with a constant temperature of 25 °C or without temperature control in different photocatalyst systems. In comparison with the condition without temperature control, all the WOZ composites display a clear decrease at the fixed temperature of 25 °C. The results above show that the photocatalytic activity of WOZ heterojunctions was greatly enhanced by the photothermal effect. Moreover, the activation energy (Ea) of the reaction was determined by fitting the experimental data on the basis of the Arrhenius equation [27,45]. The detailed procedure of the activation energy fitting is given in Text S3 of Supporting information and the results are displayed in Fig. 5(g). Surprisingly, the Ea significantly decrease from 21.90 kJ mol−1 (ZIS) to 12.47 kJ mol−1 (WOZ-60) under 300 W Xe light irradiation, illustrating that the activation energy of the reaction is greatly reduced.

The stability of as-prepared photocatalysts was assessed by the recyclability experiment. As illustrated in Fig. S4a, the conversion and selectivity of BA to BAD over WOZ-60 exhibits no evident decline during 4 cycles. Moreover, the crystal structure of WOZ-60 after four cycles of recycling utilization was determined by XRD. Moreover, as can be seen from Fig. S4b, the WOZ-60 heterojunctions remain unchanged phase structure with the typical diffraction peak at 2θ = 23.47, 27.56, and 47.4° belonging to (0 1 0) crystal planes of W18O49, (0 0 6) and (1 1 0) crystal facets of ZIS, respectively. Besides, the XPS, UV-Vis DRS, and TEM were also carried out to fully inspect the photo-stability of the WOZ-60 after cycle experiments. The XPS results of the used WOZ-60 are shown in Fig. S5. Clearly, the surface elemental composition and the valence state of the used WOZ-60 photocatalysts are the same as those of the fresh WOZ-60 photocatalysts. Moreover, as can be seen from Fig. S6a, the used WOZ-60 photocatalysts still exhibit strong absorption ability in the range of visible light and NIR light. And for the morphologies of the used WOZ-60 photocatalysts, the W18O49 nanodots were still uniformly attached on the ZIS nanosheets (Fig. S6b). These results confirm that the WOZ photocatalysts with photothermal effects are extremely steady.

A series of free-radical-capture experiments were measured to determine the mechanism of photocatalytic selective oxidation of BA over WOZ heterojunctions under the visible/NIR light irradiation (λ > 400 nm). To this end, p-benzoquinone (p-BQ), Sodium oxalate (Na2C2O4), isopropanol (IPA) and cupric chloride (CuCl2) was added to capture the •O2 ¯, •OH, holes (h+) and electrons (e-), respectively [10,11]. As displayed in Fig. 6(a), there is almost no change in the conversion of BA after adding the IPA, demonstrating •OH does not take part in the oxidation of BA. However, with the introduction of p-benzoquinone (p-BQ), the conversion of BA to BAD is greatly suppressed, indicating the •O2 ¯ is the main active species for BA oxidation. When the Na2C2O4 and CuCl2 are added, the photocatalytic activity of BA oxidation shows a decrease, revealing h+ and e- also have an effect on the BA oxidation. On the one hand, a part of BA can be oxidized directly to BAD by h+. On the other hand, photo-generated electrons can combine with O2 to produce •O2 ¯ and indirectly participate in the conversion of BA. Therefore, it can be believed that the effective molecular oxygen activation to produce •O2 ¯ plays a decisive role in the efficient oxidation of BA.

To explore the activation behavior of molecular oxygen over the as-prepared photocatalysts, the degradation experiment of NBT was measured to determine the yield of •O2 ¯. As known, the stoichiometry of NBT and superoxide radical was 1:1 [51]. Hence, the yield of •O2 ¯ shows a positive correlation with the degradation ratios of NBT. As illustrated in Fig. 6(b), under the visible/NIR light irradiation without temperature control, the degradation ratios of NBT over ZIS and WOZ-60 are 7.5% and 39.2%, respectively. With the fixed temperature at 25 °C, the degradation ratio of NBT over WOZ-60 is remarkably reduced while the degradation ratio of NBT over ZIS is almost unchanged. These results are in line with the photocatalytic activity of BA oxidation, indicating the photothermal effect is conducive to the molecular oxygen activation and the generation of •O2 ¯, thereby boosting the photocatalytic performance. Moreover, the effect of the temperature on the degradation ratios of NBT over WOZ-60 is probed. As can be seen from Fig. 6(c), when the reaction temperature was kept in constant values at 15 °C, 25 °C, 40 °C and 55 °C, the degradation ratios of NBT over WOZ-60 are 23.1%, 27.4%, 32.6% and 40.7%, respectively. The degradation ratios of NBT obviously increase with the rising of temperature. This result manifests that the increase of temperature can improve the yield of •O2 ¯ over WOZ-60, thus enhancing the conversion of BA to BAD. Moreover, at room temperature (26.1 °C), the degradation ratio of NBT under the condition without control temperature is similar to that at the constant temperature of 55 °C. These results also indicate the photothermal effect can promote the activation behavior of molecular oxygen to produce •O2 ¯, thus realizing selective oxidation of BA efficiently. To further verify the enhancement of the molecular oxygen activation induced by the photothermal effect, the DMPO spin-trapping EPR spectrum was employed to study the generation of •O2 ¯ over W18O49, ZIS and WOZ-60 under different conditions. As displayed in Fig. 6(d), the DMPO-•O2 ¯ signal was measured at the fixed reaction temperature or without control temperature under the visible/NIR light irradiation. For WOZ-60, compared to the constant reaction temperature at 25 °C, DMPO-•O2 ¯ signal intensities without temperature control are much stronger. For ZIS, the DMPO-•O2 ¯ signal intensities without temperature control are similar to that with the fixed temperature at 25 °C. In addition, Fig. S7 shows the DMPO-•O2 ¯ signal detected over the pure W18O49 under light irradiation, and over the WOZ sample at 55 °C without light irradiation. It can’t observe the DMPO-•O2 ¯ signal over the WOZ sample at 55 °C without light irradiation. And without temperature control, the DMPO-•O2 ¯ signal over the pure W18O49 is far weaker than that over WOZ-60 heterojunctions under light irradiation. These results exclude the pure thermal effect for activation of O2. Therefore, the photothermal effect induced enhanced molecular oxygen activation over WOZ-60 heterojunctions plays an important role in the high photocatalytic activity of BA selective oxidation, which agrees well with the results of the NBT degradation experiment.

In addition, the EPR results also reveal the photogenerated charge separation mechanism of the WOZ heterojunctions under the visible/NIR light irradiation (> 400 nm) [48,50]. Fig. S8a and b show the possible photogenerated charge transfer pathway of WOZ. If the transfer pathway of the photogenerated carriers follows the conventional type-II mechanism over WOZ heterojunction (Fig. S8a), the photogenerated electrons will accumulate at the CB of W18O49. In this situation, the ability of WOZ heterojunctions to produce •O2 ¯ will be weakened, which is contrary to the results of the NBT degradation experiment and EPR results. Hence, the Z-scheme heterojunction mechanism (Fig. S8b) would be more suitable to explain the transfer route of photogenerated carriers over WOZ heterojunctions instead of the traditional type-II heterojunction mechanism. Compared to type-II heterojunctions, the reductive and oxidative active sites of Z-scheme heterojunctions are spatially separated, which makes the constituent photocatalysts maintain strong redox capability and maximize the use of charge carriers.

Furthermore, we investigate the separation efficiency of the photogenerated carriers of ZIS, W18O49, and WOZ heterojunctions by photoelectrochemical measurements. Fig. 7(a) displays the electrochemical impedance spectrum (EIS) of ZIS, W18O49 and WOZ-60. Obviously, the arc radius of WOZ-60 in the Nyquist plot is smaller than that of pure ZIS and W18O49, indicating the smallest transfer resistance of the interface electrons over WOZ-60. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 7(b), the photocurrent density of WOZ-60 is much higher than that of pure ZIS and W18O49, strongly validating that the recombination of photogenerated carriers was greatly restrained after a load of W18O49 nanodots on the surface of ZIS nanosheets. The inhibition of the recombination of photogenerated carriers is more conducive to the enhancement of photocatalytic activity. Moreover, the photoluminescence (PL) spectra and time-resolved PL decay spectroscopy (TPRL) were carried out. Fig. 7(c) shows the photoluminescence (PL) spectra of as-prepared photocatalysts. As shown, a weaker PL intensity can be clearly observed in WOZ-60 compared to pure ZIS and W18O49, which is ascribed to the higher separation and transport efficiency of photogenerated electrons in WOZ-60. The TRPL decay spectra of WOZ-60 and ZIS were displayed in Fig. 7(d). Obviously, the average PL lifetime of WOZ-60 is longer (4.33 ns) than that of ZIS (2.82 ns). Hence, the formation of WOZ heterojunction can greatly improve the generation efficiency of photogenerated electron-hole pairs and prolong the lifetime of the photo-excited electrons, which increases the probability of electrons participating in surface reactions such as the MOA to produce •O2 ¯ and enhance photocatalytic performance.

Usually, the efficiency of MOA is associated with the energy of the photogenerated electrons, and a more efficient MOA can be realized by the hot electrons with higher energies. To understand the relationships between the hot electrons injection process and reaction activation, the photocatlytic activities of BA oxidation over ZIS, W18O49 and WOZ-60 were determined under NIR light irradiation (λ > 720 nm). The reaction temperature is fixed at 25 °C to reduce the influence of the photothermal effect. As shown in Fig. 8(a), after reaction for 6 h, almost no BAD can be detected with the addition of pure ZIS, indicating ZIS nanosheets can’t be excited under NIR light irradiation. While the W18O49 nanodots show a clear photocatalytic activity because of the LSPR excitation and the conversion of BA is 3.4%. More importantly, the WOZ-60 exhibits a higher conversion for photocatalytic BA oxidation (41.8%). The major reason for the enhanced photocatalytic performance of the plasmonic WOZ heterojunctions under NIR light irradiation is the ultrafast transfer of plasmon-induced hot electrons from W18O49 nanodots to ZIS nanosheets [44]. Moreover, to demonstrate the hot electrons injection process, the free-radical-capture experiments and the DMPO spin trapping EPR spectrum were also measured under the NIR light irradiation. From the results of the free-radical-capture experiments (Fig. 8b), the h+, e- and •O2 ¯ all were the active species for BA oxidation under NIR light irradiation and the •O2 ¯ played the most important role. As displayed in the EPR results (Fig. 8c), the WOZ-60 heterojunctions possess a relatively strong DMPO-•O2 ¯- signal intensity while the pure ZIS showed no DMPO-•O2 ¯ signal, indicating the generation of •O2 ¯ over WOZ-60 under NIR light irradiation. As known, under NIR light irradiation, an LSPR effect can be realized over W18O49 due to the oxygen vacancies on the surface, thereby generating hot electrons. However, due to the more negative potential than that of O2/•O2 ¯, the generated hot electrons at the CB of W18O49 can’t realize the efficient MOA. Therefore, the overall pathways of the hot electrons for the MOA process of WOZ heterojunctions under NIR light irradiation are shown in Fig. 8(d), the hot electrons at the CB of W18O49 tend to inject the CB of ZIS continuously, thus enhancing the electron density of ZIS remarkably and achieving high efficient MOA process to produce abundant •O2 ¯ [40,42].

To get more insight into the effect of the hot electrons injection process on the MOA, the DFT calculations were carried out. As known, the work function (WF) can be determined by the vacuum energy (Ev) and Fermi energy (Ef) according to the formula WF = Ef – Ev [52]. As shown in Fig. 9(a) and (b), after coupling with W18O49, the work function (WF) of ZIS is dramatically reduced from 3.97 eV to 0.68 eV. The much smaller WF of WOZ heterojunctions indicates the higher energy of its ground-state surface electrons, which are more easily to escape from the surface and take part in the MOA. Besides, the UPS spectra were used to further detect the change of the WF over ZIS and WOZ heterojunctions and the results are displayed in Fig. S9a. According to the UPS data, the WF of ZIS and WOZ-60 is calculated to be 5.19 eV and 4.68 eV, respectively. It is obvious that loading W18O49 nanodots decrease the WF of ZIS, which is in line with the DFT results. The detailed calculation procedure of the WF is in Text S4. Furthermore, the O2-TPD experiments were utilized to investigate the chemisorption and activation processes of O2 molecules over ZIS and WOZ-60 heterojunctions. As illustrated in Fig. S9b, in comparison with pure ZIS, more desorbed peaks can be observed in the and the desorbed peaks shift to higher temperature over WOZ-60 heterojunctions, indicating the great promotion of the chemisorption and activation ability of WOZ-60 heterojunctions to O2 molecules. These results further prove the DFT results. Moreover, the energy of electrons was modified by the Vanderbilt ultrasoft pseudopotentials on the basis of the lowest-energy principle. Obviously, the work function WF of WOZ with a neutral surface [WOZ] was higher than that of WOZ with a positive charges surface [WOZ]+ while lower than that of WOZ with a negative charges surface [WOZ]- (Fig. 9c and d). This result indicates the energy of surface electrons over WOZ heterojunctions increased with its surface charges changing from positive to negative. Generally, the increasing energy of the electrons can enhance the interaction between the catalyst surface and adsorbed O2 and make O2 more reactive [45]. Meanwhile, as illustrated in Fig. 9(e)–(g), the adsorption energy (Eabs) of O2 on [WOZ]-, [WOZ] and [WOZ]+ are calculated to be −0.22, −0.08 and 0.25 eV, respectively, further verifying the electrons with higher energies can adsorb and activate the molecular oxygen more easily [53]. Hence, the hot electrons injection process over WOZ heterojunctions can provide the electrons with higher energy continuously and activate the molecular oxygen more easily and effectively to produce •O2 ¯, which agrees with the free-radical-capture experiments and the EPR results under NIR light irradiation.

Based on the analysis above, we can propose a probable mechanism for efficient photocatalytic oxidation of BA over plasmonic WOZ heterojunctions. As shown in Fig. 10, the transfer pathway of photoinduced carriers of WOZ heterojunctions follows the Z-scheme mechanism, which can enhance the charge separation efficiency and carriers migration capacity, thus resulting in higher photocatalytic activity. Under visible/NIR light irradiation, both ZIS and W18O49 can be photoexcited and produce electron-hole pairs. Then the photoinduced electrons on the CB of W18O49 will move to the VB of ZIS and rapidly combined with photoinduced holes on it. So the electrons maintain at the CB of ZIS with the strong reducibility and activate the adsorbed O2 on photocatalyst surface to produce •O2 ¯, which participate in the BA selective oxidation. Meanwhile, the photo-generated holes accumulate in the VB of W18O49 with strong oxidation ability and convert the BA to BAD. Meanwhile, because of the LSPR effect of W18O49, the generated hot electrons with higher energy will inject into the CB of ZIS continuously and increase its electron density greatly. It can enhance the interaction between the catalyst surface and adsorbed O2, thus improving the ability of molecular oxygen activation over WOZ heterojunctions. Besides the LSPR-induced hot electrons injection process, during the photocatalytic reaction of BA selective oxidation, the efficiency of the MOA to produce •O2 ¯ will be further promoted by the photothermal effect of WOZ heterojunctions. The average energy of electrons will increase with the higher temperature, which enhances their potential to take part in the MOA and generate more •O2 ¯radicals. Moreover, the potential conversion pathways from BA to BAD are put forward in Fig S10b [54,55]. At first, the BA will undergo a deprotonation process to generate alkoxide anion BA¯ with the help of the photo-generated holes and •O2 ¯radicals. Subsequently, an electron transfer process takes place over the BA¯, thus producing the benzyloxy •BA. Finally, under the effect of the holes and •O2 ¯, a further oxidation reaction occurs on •BA to form BAD. From the analysis above, we conclude that the synergy among photothermal effect and continuous hot electrons injection greatly enhance the efficiency of MOA to produce a tremendous amount of •O2 ¯, thus realizing efficient oxidation of BA. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report on the studies about revealing the promotion of the MOA induced by the synergistic effect of photothermal effect and continuous hot electrons injection.

In summary, the plasmonic 0D/2D W18O49/ZIS (WOZ) heterojunctions with photothermal effect were successfully constructed through a facile water-bath heating method. The conversion of BA to BAD of WOZ-60 was the highest, which was 3.1 and 18.6 times of pure ZIS and W18O49, respectively. Moreover, the WOZ heterojunctions showed excellent stability. The superior photocatalytic activity of WOZ heterojunctions included three aspects of reason. First, the LSPR effect of W18O49 loading expanded the light absorption edge of the WOZ heterojunctions from the visible to the near-infrared region, improving the utilization of light energy. Second, the separation and transport efficiency of photogenerated carriers were greatly promoted due to the Z-scheme transfer pathway of WOZ heterojunctions. More importantly, based on the experiments and DFT calculations, the molecular oxygen can be activated efficiently and rapidly by the synergism of photothermal effect and continuous hot electrons injection over to produce abundant •O2 ¯, resulting in the significant improvement of photocatalytic activity for BA oxidation of WOZ heterojunctions. This work not only firstly revealed the promotion of the MOA induced by the synergistic effect of photothermal effect and continuous hot electrons injection, but also provided a new strategy to construct more active photothermal catalysts for a wide variety of organic transformations with solar energy.
